Title: IRAQ WRAPUP 5-Barack Obama meets PM Maliki in Baghdad
URL: IRAQ WRAPUP 5-Barack Obama meets PM Maliki in Baghdad.txt
Text: * Obama meets Prime Minister Maliki      * Wants U.S. combat troops out in 16 months if wins election      * Maliki has suggested setting withdrawal timetable            By Dean Yates and Wisam Mohammed      BAGHDAD, July 21 (Reuters) - U.S. Democratic presidential  candidate Barack Obama met Iraq's prime minister on Monday to  get a first-hand assessment of security in the country, where  violence is at its lowest level since early 2004.      His visit thrusts U.S. strategy in Iraq and troop levels to  the centre of the November election race between the first-term  senator from Illinois and Republican candidate John McCain.  There are more than 140,000 U.S. soldiers in Iraq.      Obama has called for the removal of U.S. combat troops  within 16 months of taking office should he win the election.      Iraqiya state television and witnesses said Obama met Prime  Minister Nuri al-Maliki in Baghdad. There were no further  details on Obama's visit, which has been shrouded in secrecy for  security reasons.      Obama visited Afghanistan over the weekend, the other big  foreign policy challenge the next American president will face.  He called the situation in Afghanistan 'precarious and urgent'  and said Washington should start planning to transfer more  troops there from Iraq.      Maliki suggested earlier this month setting a timetable for  U.S. troops to leave Iraq but has given no dates.      Obama has welcomed Maliki's suggestion but some Iraqis  insist that the army and police cannot go it alone and that a  premature withdrawal of U.S. troops could open the door to the  sort of violence that nearly tore Iraq apart not so long ago.      On Sunday the Iraqi government denied Maliki told a German  magazine in an interview that he backed Obama's plan to withdraw  combat troops within 16 months. The government said Maliki's  remarks to Der Spiegel were translated incorrectly.       McCain has attacked Obama for not visiting Iraq recently to  get a first-hand look at conditions.      The Republican candidate has been to Iraq eight times while  Obama's only other trip was in January 2006, a month before  militants blew up a revered Shi'ite shrine in Samarra in an  attack that plunged Iraq into vicious sectarian fighting.      The U.S. embassy said Obama, who is visiting Iraq as part of  a U.S. congressional delegation, would also meet U.S. military  commanders and American troops.      Commanders are likely to tell Obama that security gains are  fragile and could be jeopardised by a hasty troop withdrawal.      Obama, trying to boost his foreign policy credentials, will  travel to other countries in the Middle East and visit major  powers in Europe this week.      He has scheduled no news conferences in Iraq.            OBAMA SAYS WANTS TO END THE WAR      Obama courted controversy on July 3 when he said he might  'refine' his views on withdrawing combat troops from Iraq within  16 months but later said his stance had been unchanged for more  than a year and that he intended 'to end this war'.      McCain says the U.S. troop buildup last year helped boost  stability in Iraq and has criticised the Democrat's vow to order  a quick withdrawal as 'reckless'.      But the dramatic reduction in violence has led Baghdad to  become increasingly assertive about its own security  capabilities.      Indeed, Maliki and President George W. Bush agreed last week  to set a 'time horizon' for reducing American forces in Iraq.      It was the closest the

sentences.text: His visit thrusts U.S. strategy in Iraq and troop levels to the centre of the November election race between the first-term senator from Illinois and Republican candidate John McCain. There are more than 140,000 U.S. soldiers in Iraq.
sentences.bias_description: The phrase 'thrusts U.S. strategy' implies a sudden and forceful action, suggesting a judgment that this visit significantly impacts the election race, which could influence the reader's perception.

sentences.text: Obama has called for the removal of U.S. combat troops within 16 months of taking office should he win the election.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'called for' implies a request or demand, which could subtly suggest to the reader that this is an extreme or challenging position, potentially influencing their perception of the feasibility or reasonableness of the proposal.

sentences.text: Obama visited Afghanistan over the weekend, the other big foreign policy challenge the next American president will face. He called the situation in Afghanistan 'precarious and urgent' and said Washington should start planning to transfer more troops there from Iraq.
sentences.bias_description: Describing Afghanistan as 'the other big foreign policy challenge' and the situation as 'precarious and urgent' uses language that emphasizes the severity and importance of the issue, potentially leading the reader to prioritize it over other matters.

sentences.text: Obama has welcomed Maliki's suggestion but some Iraqis insist that the army and police cannot go it alone and that a premature withdrawal of U.S. troops could open the door to the sort of violence that nearly tore Iraq apart not so long ago.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence presents the opinion that a premature withdrawal of U.S. troops could lead to significant violence as a fact, without providing evidence or acknowledging alternative viewpoints, thus blurring the line between opinion and objective reporting.

sentences.text: On Sunday the Iraqi government denied Maliki told a German magazine in an interview that he backed Obama's plan to withdraw combat troops within 16 months. The government said Maliki's remarks to Der Spiegel were translated incorrectly.
sentences.bias_description: The use of 'denied' and the detailed explanation of the translation issue could imply to the reader that there is a deliberate attempt to undermine or distort Maliki's position, potentially casting doubt on the integrity of the information.

sentences.text: McCain has attacked Obama for not visiting Iraq recently to get a first-hand look at conditions. The Republican candidate has been to Iraq eight times while Obama's only other trip was in January 2006, a month before militants blew up a revered Shi'ite shrine in Samarra in an attack that plunged Iraq into vicious sectarian fighting.
sentences.bias_description: The framing of McCain's criticism and the detailed comparison of his and Obama's visits to Iraq could subtly suggest to the reader that Obama's understanding of the situation in Iraq is lacking or inferior, potentially influencing their perception of his qualifications.

sentences.text: Commanders are likely to tell Obama that security gains are fragile and could be jeopardised by a hasty troop withdrawal.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence speculates on what commanders might tell Obama, implying a negative outcome ('fragile' security gains jeopardized by 'hasty' troop withdrawal) without presenting concrete evidence or the full range of expert opinions on the matter.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding the discussion of U.S. strategy in Iraq, particularly in the context of the 2008 presidential election, with a general bias tendency towards portraying certain positions and actions in a more negative or challenging light.

Title: IRAQ WRAPUP 1-Barack Obama visits Iraq, focus on war strategy
URL: IRAQ WRAPUP 1-Barack Obama visits Iraq, focus on war strategy.txt
Text: * Obama to meet Iraqi leaders, U.S. commanders      * Wants U.S. combat troops out in 16 months if wins election      * Obama last visited Iraq in January 2006            By Dean Yates      BAGHDAD, July 21 (Reuters) - U.S. Democratic presidential  candidate Barack Obama flew into Baghdad on Monday, officials  said, thrusting U.S. strategy in Iraq and troop levels to the  centre-stage of the November election race.      Obama has called for the removal of U.S. combat troops from  Iraq within 16 months of taking office should he win the  election. He visited Afghanistan over the weekend, the other big  foreign policy challenge the next American president will face.      Obama has come under attack from Republican candidate John  McCain for not making a recent visit to assess conditions in  Iraq, where violence is at a four-year low. McCain has been to  Iraq eight times while Obama's only other trip was in 2006.      The U.S. embassy said Obama, who is visiting Iraq as part of  a U.S. congressional delegation, would meet senior Iraqi  officials and U.S. military commanders.      Seeking to boost his foreign policy credentials, Obama will  travel to other countries in the Middle East and also visit  major powers in Europe this week.      Obama courted controversy on July 3 when he said he might  'refine' his views on withdrawing combat troops from Iraq within  16 months but later said his stance had been unchanged for more  than a year and that he intended 'to end this war'.      McCain says a U.S. troop buildup last year helped boost  stability in Iraq and has criticised Democrats' vows for a quick  withdrawal as 'reckless'.      But with violence down dramatically, Baghdad has become  increasingly assertive about its own security capabilities.      Indeed, Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki and President  George W. Bush agreed late last week to set a 'time horizon' for  reducing American forces in Iraq.      It was the closest the Bush administration has come to  acknowledging the need for a timeframe for U.S. troop cuts. Bush  has long opposed deadlines for troop withdrawals.      Maliki earlier this month suggested setting a timetable for  U.S. troops to leave Iraq, although he had given no dates.      But the Iraqi government has denied Maliki told a German  magazine in an interview released on Saturday that he backed  Obama's plan to withdraw combat troops within 16 months.      The government has said Maliki's remarks to Der Spiegel were  misunderstood and translated incorrectly.       In a speech last Tuesday, Obama said a 'single-minded' focus  on Iraq was distracting the United States from other threats,  and he promised to shift resources to fighting al Qaeda and the  Taliban in Afghanistan.      Obama called the situation in Afghanistan 'precarious and  urgent' on Sunday and said Washington should start planning to  transfer more troops there from Iraq.      ((dean.yates@thomsonreuters.com; Reuters Messaging:  dean.yates.reuters.com@reuters.net))    Keywords: IRAQ/

sentences.text: Obama has come under attack from Republican candidate John McCain for not making a recent visit to assess conditions in Iraq, where violence is at a four-year low. McCain has been to Iraq eight times while Obama's only other trip was in 2006.
sentences.bias_description: The sentence uses language that implicitly criticizes Obama's approach by highlighting the contrast with McCain's visits, suggesting a judgment about Obama's commitment to understanding the situation in Iraq.

sentences.text: Obama courted controversy on July 3 when he said he might 'refine' his views on withdrawing combat troops from Iraq within 16 months but later said his stance had been unchanged for more than a year and that he intended 'to end this war'.
sentences.bias_description: The use of the phrase 'courted controversy' implies a negative connotation to Obama's actions, suggesting that his statement was provocative or unnecessary, which could influence the reader's perception.

sentences.text: McCain says a U.S. troop buildup last year helped boost stability in Iraq and has criticised Democrats' vows for a quick withdrawal as 'reckless'.
sentences.bias_description: Describing the Democrats' position as 'reckless' without providing a counterargument from the Democrats' perspective introduces a negative judgment and implies that the Democratic approach is irresponsible or dangerous.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias through the use of word choice, particularly in the framing of Obama's and the Democrats' positions in contrast to McCain's, which could influence the reader's perception of the political figures and their strategies regarding the Iraq war.

Title: FACTBOX-Five facts about U.S. Democrat Barack Obama
URL: FACTBOX-Five facts about U.S. Democrat Barack Obama.txt
Text: Jan 3 (Reuters) - Barack Obama won the Democratic nominating  contest in Iowa on Thursday, a major step in his bid to beat rival  Hillary Clinton and become their party's presidential pick for the  November general election.      Here are five facts about the Illinois Senator who aims to  become the first black president of the United States:           *Obama's father was born and raised in a village in Kenya; his  mother, who was white, grew up in Kansas.           *Obama grew up in Hawaii and Indonesia. He earned his law  degree from Harvard in 1991 and was the first African-American  president of the Harvard Law Review.           *He is married to wife Michelle and has two young  daughters.           *He was a member of the Illinois State Senate before being  elected to the U.S. Senate. His speech at the Democratic  National Convention in 2004 earned him national attention and  acclaim.           *On issues key to many Democratic voters, Obama favors  withdrawing U.S. troops from Iraq, reducing carbon emissions to  fight climate change, and eliminating tax breaks from companies  that move jobs overseas.            (Writing by Jeff Mason in Washington; editing by Stuart  Grudgings)    ((jeff.mason@reuters.com, +1 202 310 5487, Reuters Messaging:  jeff.mason.reuters.com@reuters.net)       Keywords: USA POLITICS/OBAMA

overall_bias.conclusion: The article does not seem to be biased as it provides factual information about Barack Obama's background and political positions without using language that implies judgment or promotes a specific narrative.

Title: SNAP ANALYSIS-Obama pledges return to science, energy policy
URL: SNAP ANALYSIS-Obama pledges return to science, energy policy.txt
Text: By Maggie Fox, Health and Science Editor      WASHINGTON, Jan 20 (Reuters) - U.S. President Barack Obama  pledged a return to science in his inaugural address on  Tuesday, promising a rational approach to transform health care  and action toward an alternative energy policy.      Making a clear break with his predecessor George W. Bush,  Obama repeated campaign promises to 'restore science to its  rightful place'.      * The Bush administration was criticized for packing  scientific advisory panels with industry representatives and  ideologues and Obama's promise suggests a return to a policy of  seeking knowledgeable, non-partisan advisers.      * Bush's anti-abortion policy had a wide influence, from  AIDS programs overseas to breast cancer research at the  National Cancer Institute. Obama is expected to reverse a  Health and Human Services Department regulation aimed at  protecting health care and other workers who invoke their  consciences in refusing care such as contraceptive services.      * Obama is also widely expected to quickly reverse Bush's  executive order that has had the effect of limiting embryonic  stem cell research. Former Surgeon-General Dr. Richard Carmona  complained he was muzzled in attempts to speak out on stem cell  science and other issues.      * Obama also pledged to 'wield technology's wonders to  raise health care's quality and lower its cost'. In his  campaign Obama pledged to spend billions to promote and  facilitate electronic prescribing and record-keeping.      * Obama suggested funding for alternative energy. 'We will  harness the sun and the winds and the soil to fuel our cars and  run our factories,' he said.      * The Bush administration was slow to accept that human  activities had affected global warming. Former Environmental  Protection Agency head Christine Todd Whitman has complained  the White House interfered with her agency's work.   (Writing by Maggie Fox; Editing by David Storey)   ((Maggie.Fox@Reuters.com; 1 202 898 8492))   ((For full U.S. political coverage double click on  [US/VOTE]))  Keywords: OBAMA/SCIENCE

sentences.text: The Bush administration was criticized for packing scientific advisory panels with industry representatives and ideologues and Obama's promise suggests a return to a policy of seeking knowledgeable, non-partisan advisers.
sentences.bias_description: The use of the word 'ideologues' to describe the Bush administration's scientific advisory panel members implies a negative connotation and suggests that their decisions were based on personal beliefs rather than scientific evidence, which is a form of Word Choice Bias.

sentences.text: Bush's anti-abortion policy had a wide influence, from AIDS programs overseas to breast cancer research at the National Cancer Institute. Obama is expected to reverse a Health and Human Services Department regulation aimed at protecting health care and other workers who invoke their consciences in refusing care such as contraceptive services.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence exhibits Political Bias by framing the issue of abortion in a way that implies negative consequences of the Bush administration's policy on unrelated health programs, suggesting a one-sided negative impact without a balanced view.

sentences.text: Former Surgeon-General Dr. Richard Carmona complained he was muzzled in attempts to speak out on stem cell science and other issues.
sentences.bias_description: The use of the word 'muzzled' to describe the actions taken against Dr. Richard Carmona implies a deliberate and unjust suppression of information, which is a form of Word Choice Bias that suggests a strong negative judgment on the Bush administration's handling of scientific discourse.

sentences.text: The Bush administration was slow to accept that human activities had affected global warming. Former Environmental Protection Agency head Christine Todd Whitman has complained the White House interfered with her agency's work.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence demonstrates Political Bias by highlighting the Bush administration's stance on global warming in a way that implies negligence or deliberate obstruction, without providing a balanced view or considering the complexities of policy-making and scientific consensus at the time.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article exhibits bias regarding the comparison between the Obama and Bush administrations' approaches to science and health policies. The biases identified include Word Choice Bias and Political Bias, with a general tendency to portray the Obama administration's approach as more favorable and scientifically sound compared to the Bush administration's, without presenting a balanced perspective.

Title: Obama vows "best and brightest" foreign policy team
URL: Obama vows "best and brightest" foreign policy team.txt
Text: By Caren Bohan      CHESTER, Va., Aug 21 (Reuters) - U.S. presidential  candidate Barack Obama said on Thursday he would assemble a  foreign policy team of the 'best and the brightest' and  mentioned some people who may be considered for jobs if he wins  the White House.      Former Georgia senator Sam Nunn and former U.S. diplomat  Richard Holbrooke were among the Democrats Obama said he would  turn to for advice.      The presumptive Democratic presidential nominee said he  would also seek the counsel of Republicans such as Indiana Sen.  Richard Lugar and Nebraska Sen. Chuck Hagel.      Republican John McCain, Obama's rival in the Nov. 4  election, has emphasized his background as a Vietnam veteran  and former prisoner of war as well as years of involvement as a  senator in foreign policy to argue that he is more qualified to  serve as U.S. commander-in-chief.      McCain accuses Obama, a first-term Illinois senator, of  lacking seasoning and judgment on foreign policy matters.      At a town hall meeting in Chester, Virginia, Obama said his  early opposition to the Iraq war showed he had better judgment  than McCain, who supported it.      But he added, 'That doesn't mean that I know everything.  I've got to have good, smart advisers around me ... It's not  like I just kind of show up, you know, one day in the White  House and say, 'Alright, what's today?''      Listing those he already consults on foreign affairs, Obama  mentioned Nunn, Holbrooke and former Secretary of Defense  William Perry.      'We will have the best and brightest -- and by the way,  they don't have to be Democrats,' he said. 'There are  Republicans like Richard Lugar, the chairman of the (Senate)  Foreign Relations committee, who is one of my dearest friends  and advisers in the Senate.'      Obama also recalled his trip in July to Iraq and  Afghanistan with Hagel.      'He's a staunch Republican, but Chuck and I agree almost on  every item of foreign policy,' he said.   (Reporting by Caren Bohan, editing by David Storey)   ((For more about the U.S. political campaign, visit Reuters  'Tales from the Trail: 2008' online at  http://blogs.reuters.com/trail08/))    ((For a TAKE A LOOK on the campaign click on [US/VOTE]))  Keywords: USA POLITICS/OBAMA FOREIGNPOLICY

overall_bias.conclusion: The article does not seem to be biased as it primarily reports on Barack Obama's statements regarding his foreign policy team without using language or framing that indicates a bias.

Title: We Now Know How Barack Obama Will Govern.txt
URL: We Now Know How Barack Obama Will Govern.txt.txt
Text:
With the announcement Friday that President Obama will leave about 50,000 troops in Iraq after the bulk of U.S. forces withdraw in 2010, it is becoming clear that on foreign policy the president will govern from the center.

But it is also now certain that he is a far-left guy on domestic policy. The new budget is simply stunning. Mr. Obama wants to spend more money than at any time since World War II.

Predictably, quasi-socialists like New York Times columnist Paul Krugman are delirious with joy. Here comes the nanny state, starring President Obama and Fran Drescher.

Also predictably, conservatives like Glenn Beck are outfitting caves in the mountains. The decline and fall of America is at hand.

"Talking Points" cannot imagine any Republican senator supporting the massive budget, so it will have trouble getting passed.

But the die has been cast. President Obama is "all in" for a colossal change in American society. That change means the rich will support the poor. Americans who do not succeed will have their bills paid by people like me — and Barack Obama when he becomes a private citizen again.

That also means we'll have some kind of new energy in this country, but nobody knows when or what. However, there's plenty of money that will fund the mystery.

And gazillions more dollars will flow into America's schools. What this will do, I don't know because if the kids walk around all day with iPods in their ears and rings in their noses, money simply won't matter.

Now, "Talking Points" knows he's a mean guy. Criticizing the kids? Come on, how can I do that? Whining about paying other people's bills? That's just downright mean, is it not?

Well that's how the far-left is portraying it. Listen to this new commercial from some progressive loons:

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: An economy in crisis, a president determined to act, but what did Republican leaders say to President Obama's jobs and recovery plan?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What did they say to 3.5 million jobs?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What did they say to tax cuts for 95 percent of working Americans?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So who are Republican leaders listening to?

RUSH LIMBAUGH, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: I want him to fail.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Tell them America won't take no for an answer anymore.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

That's what passes for debate these days on the far left: running down anyone with whom they disagree.

But as "Talking Points" said Thursday night, President Obama is taking an enormous gamble, one that will affect all of our lives. He has audacity, no question. But the outcome is still mostly hope.

And that's "The Memo."

Pinheads & Patriots

Once a year the Filene's Basement department store here in New York City mounts a sale called the "Running of the Brides." The ladies line up hours ahead of time to get discounts on wedding dresses, and then when the doors open the track meet begins. The excitement is generated by dresses that once cost thousands of dollars marked down to hundreds of dollars.

Now this might be a stretch, but I'm making the ladies patriots because they are thrifty, and we need that in America. So there.

On the pinhead front, welcome to Will Ferrell's world. The comedian, currently starring in the hit Broadway play about President Bush, started out as the "Senior Prince of the Winter Ball" at University High School in Irvine, California.

Click here to see the picture!

Now anyone seeing this picture back then could have predicted Mr. Ferrell would achieve great success. The only mystery: in what area?

Pinhead? You make the call.

— You can catch Bill O'Reilly's "Talking Points Memo" and "Pinheads & Patriots" weeknights at 8 and 11 p.m. ET on the FOX News Channel and any time on foxnews.com/oreilly. Send your comments to: oreilly@foxnews.com

sentences.text: But it is also now certain that he is a far-left guy on domestic policy. The new budget is simply stunning. Mr. Obama wants to spend more money than at any time since World War II.
sentences.bias_description: The use of the phrase 'far-left guy' and 'simply stunning' to describe President Obama's domestic policy and budget choices implies a negative judgment and suggests a lack of objectivity.

sentences.text: Predictably, quasi-socialists like New York Times columnist Paul Krugman are delirious with joy. Here comes the nanny state, starring President Obama and Fran Drescher.
sentences.bias_description: Referring to individuals as 'quasi-socialists' and using phrases like 'delirious with joy' and 'nanny state' introduces a negative connotation and implies a dismissive attitude towards those who support President Obama's policies.

sentences.text: Also predictably, conservatives like Glenn Beck are outfitting caves in the mountains. The decline and fall of America is at hand.
sentences.bias_description: The dramatic language used to describe the reaction of conservatives, suggesting they are preparing for doomsday, is designed to evoke a strong emotional response and exaggerates the situation.

sentences.text: But the die has been cast. President Obama is "all in" for a colossal change in American society. That change means the rich will support the poor. Americans who do not succeed will have their bills paid by people like me — and Barack Obama when he becomes a private citizen again.
sentences.bias_description: The phrase 'colossal change' and the oversimplified description of wealth redistribution imply a negative judgment and suggest a biased perspective on the proposed policies.

sentences.text: That also means we'll have some kind of new energy in this country, but nobody knows when or what. However, there's plenty of money that will fund the mystery.
sentences.bias_description: The dismissive tone towards new energy initiatives, referring to them as 'some kind of new energy' and 'plenty of money that will fund the mystery,' suggests a lack of seriousness and undermines the efforts without providing a balanced view.

sentences.text: Now, "Talking Points" knows he's a mean guy. Criticizing the kids? Come on, how can I do that? Whining about paying other people's bills? That's just downright mean, is it not?
sentences.bias_description: The self-deprecating introduction followed by the use of 'mean guy' and 'whining' to describe concerns about wealth distribution and education funding targets the character and motives of those with opposing views, rather than addressing the substance of the arguments.

sentences.text: Well that's how the far-left is portraying it. Listen to this new commercial from some progressive loons:
sentences.bias_description: Labeling individuals as 'progressive loons' employs derogatory language to discredit and dismiss their perspectives, indicating a biased and disrespectful approach to differing viewpoints.

sentences.text: That's what passes for debate these days on the far left: running down anyone with whom they disagree.
sentences.bias_description: This sentence generalizes and negatively characterizes the behavior of the 'far left' as dismissive and attacking towards opposing views, without providing specific evidence or a balanced perspective.

sentences.text: But as "Talking Points" said Thursday night, President Obama is taking an enormous gamble, one that will affect all of our lives. He has audacity, no question. But the outcome is still mostly hope.
sentences.bias_description: Describing President Obama's actions as 'an enormous gamble' and using the phrase 'mostly hope' to qualify the potential outcomes introduces a skeptical and biased perspective, suggesting a lack of objectivity in the assessment.

overall_bias.conclusion: The article is biased regarding the discussion of President Obama's policies, particularly in the domestic and social policy spheres. It exhibits a general bias tendency through the use of word choice, emotional sensationalism, ad hominem attacks, and speculative language to discredit opposing viewpoints and portray the discussed policies in a negative light.

Title: Big U.S. foreign policy challenges await Obama
URL: Big U.S. foreign policy challenges await Obama.txt
Text: By Caren Bohan      CHICAGO, Nov 4 (Reuters) - Newly-elected U.S. president  Barack Obama will face a daunting array of foreign policy  challenges, from wars in Afghanistan and Iraq and the global  financial crisis to the need to shore up the country's frayed  international image.      While taxes, health care and the economy all played a role  in the campaign before Tuesday's vote, national security issues  such as the Iranian nuclear standoff and Middle East peace are  likely to remain near the top of the agenda when Obama takes  office from President George W. Bush on Jan 20.      'The mantra for the next administration has to be, 'Be  careful what you wish for because you just might get it,'' said  James Lindsay, who was a foreign policy aide to President Bill  Clinton and is now with the University of Texas, Austin.      'The new president-elect is going to have a full foreign  policy inbox and decisions to make with enormous consequences  for American security,' added Lindsay.      Foreign policy advisers say Obama, a Democrat who will  become the first black U.S. president, has an understanding of  world affairs rooted in a childhood spent partly in Indonesia  and a quest to learn about his father's Kenyan heritage.      The Illinois senator, 47, will face pressing concerns even  before he takes over from Bush, a Republican.      On Nov. 15, Bush will convene a summit in Washington to  look at the global economic crisis. While Obama is unlikely to  attend the meeting himself, it could give his economic team the  chance to meet some of the visiting foreign officials on the  sidelines of the conference.      The Obama administration will also inherit the Iraq and  Afghan wars and an intensifying effort to pursue al Qaeda  militants on Pakistan's border with Afghanistan.      Stopping Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon -- Tehran  says its nuclear program is purely for civilian purposes -- and  holding North Korea to its promise to dismantle its nuclear  weapons program are also pressing issues.           FAMILIAR NAMES, NEW APPROACHES      Obama has a number of foreign policy advisers with roots in  the Clinton administration, although he has also said he could  work with Republicans. Republican Senator Chuck Hagel and  Democratic Senator John Kerry are two names frequently  mentioned as candidates for secretary of state.      Obama, like his defeated Republican rival John McCain, has  vowed a reinvigorated effort toward Middle East peace and  promised staunch support for Israel.      Obama foreign policy adviser Mark Lippert said fighting  terrorism, dealing with militants along the Afghan-Pakistan  border and killing or capturing Osama bin Laden are top  national security priorities.      Obama has pledged to end the Iraq war and bolster the U.S.  troop presence in Afghanistan.      The ability to tackle deteriorating security in Afghanistan  and pursue militants is 'linked to the ability to make progress  on political reconciliation in Iraq and the ability to draw  down there,' Lippert said.      McCain agreed on the need for more forces in Afghanistan,  but opposed a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq, saying U.S.  troops should remain there as long as they are needed.      Obama's willingness to talk directly to U.S. adversaries  such as Iran and Syria was another major point of disagreement  during the campaign. Obama said the Bush administration's  resistance to engaging foes has limited its diplomatic options,  a posit

overall_bias.conclusion: The article does not seem to be biased as it primarily focuses on outlining the foreign policy challenges that the newly-elected U.S. president, Barack Obama, will face. The topics discussed and the language used are neutral, presenting the information in a factual manner without promoting a particular viewpoint or agenda.
